PROJECT NUMBER: 53222-001 
Transaction Technical Assistance Facility (F-TRTA) 
July 2019 
 
Preparing Sustainable Energy Projects in Central 
Asia

Policy.

FY2018 ends on 31 December 2018.  
(ii)  In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars unless otherwise stated.

I.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FACILITY 
 
A.  Justification 
 
1.  The regional transaction TA facility will provide project preparation support to a series of 
ensuing projects in Central Asia, comprising: (i) Power Distribution Enhancement, Renewable 
Energy and Energy Efficiency Projects in the Kyrgyz Republic; and (ii) Power Sector Development 
Program in the Republic of Tajikistan. In addition, the TA Facility will provide high-level screening, 
due  diligence  and  formulation  of  the  components  for  the  Sector  Development  Project  in 
Kazakhstan. All ensuing projects are in the energy sector and require a similar set of safeguard, 
financial management, or economic assessments. This TA facility is not included in the current 
Country Operations Business Plans of these 3 countries. Nevertheless, all ensuing projects under 
this transaction TA facility are listed in their current Country Operations Business Plans. 
 
2.  The electricity sector of Central Asia, developed during the former Soviet Union time, was 
primarily designed to optimize the use of water resources with electricity being a secondary 
product.  Power  plants  and  transmission  lines  were  built  without  the  consideration  of  the 
administrative boundaries, which later became national borders. After the collapse of the Soviet 
Union in 1991, the energy ministers of the Central Asian states faced a new challenge of 
autonomously operating national power grids that were not designed to do so. In addition to 
technical complexities, the energy sector in these countries followed different development paths.  
 
3.  In the Kyrgyz Republic, the electricity sector experienced major transformations. The first 
sector reform to unbundle the vertically integrated power utility into 6 companies took place in 
2000. Since then, a number of developments took place including the transfer of all state shares 
in energy companies to the newly created National Energy Holding Company (NEHC) in 2016. 
Nevertheless, aging assets, tariffs below cost recovery levels and the lack of investments for 
refurbishment and maintenance of energy assets has resulted in poor power supply reliability and 
quality with frequent outages and regular voltage and frequency fluctuations. 
 
4.  ADB has been supporting the rehabilitation of aging large hydro powerplants, including 
Toktogul hydropower plant (HPP) and Uch-Kurgan HPP, but rehabilitation is also needed for 
smaller power plants. Small HPPs of the Joint Stock Company (JSC) Chakan HPP have been in 
service for 60-89 years without major rehabilitation. They experience frequent equipment failure 
and considerable expenditures on maintenance and repair. Rehabilitation of turbine-generators 
and balance of the plant will improve generation reliability and increase the installed capacity.   
 
5.  Power distribution grid of the Kyrgyz Republic is in a similar condition. Most of the 
distribution network in Bishkek, including substations, were constructed in the 1960s and 1970s. 
Aged assets and the absence of modern supervisory control and data acquisition (SCADA) 
system result in poor reliability and service quality and leads to higher distribution losses. No 
demand-side energy efficiency programs have been implemented on a large scale even for simple 
activities such as energy efficient lighting for public and residential sectors. In addition, penetration 
of modern technologies in the electricity sector remains low.  
 
6.  In view of the challenges faced by the energy sector, the proposed intervention of ADB 
intends to address these issues in a combined manner through one multidirectional project, which 
will  focus  on  refurbishment  of  small  hydro  power  plants,  construction  of  new 
transmission/distribution assets, implementation of demand-side energy efficiency measures, 
introduction of modern technologies, and renewable energy in district heating.

2 
7.  The Tajik electricity sector faced problems similar to those in the Kyrgyz Republic.  
Generation and transmission assets were used beyond their technical and economic life, tariffs 
remained extremely low, and financing was insufficient for the sector needs. These conditions 
were exacerbated by 8 years of civil unrest in the 1990s and the disconnection of the Tajik grid 
from the Central Asian Power System (CAPS) in 2009, which severely limited the country’s trade 
opportunities and ability to supply indigenous electricity within the national grid. 
  
8.  The government responded to these issues through rehabilitation and construction of 
transmission and generation assets with financing from multilateral and bilateral development 
partners. These efforts substantially improved the electricity supply, reduced winter power deficit 
and opened new export opportunities. However, such extensive investments in combination with 
low tariffs, inadequate metering and billing system, weak governance, and lagging sector reforms 
resulted in financial insolvency of the vertically integrated state power utility, JSC Barqi Tojik. 
 
9.  ADB is the largest financier in the Tajikistan energy sector among development partners. 
In 2016, ADB provided support to develop the Electricity Market Development Strategy to address 
the sector’s financial sustainability. Reforms in this strategy were developed in close cooperation 
with the World Bank and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) and 
includes:  (i)  unbundling  of  JSC  Barqi  Tojik  into  generation,  transmission  and  distribution 
companies; (ii) establishment of a market operator; (iii) centralized cash management by creating 
a sector-wide escrow account; (iv) adoption of a new tariff methodology and establishment of the 
sector regulator; (v) restructuring of financial liabilities of JSC Barqi Tojik; (vi) installation of a new 
retail metering and billing system; and (vii) introduction of a 5-year management contract for the 
new distribution company. These reforms are supported by ADB through the proposed Power 
Sector Development Program with possible cofinancing from EBRD and the Islamic Development 
Bank.1  
 
10.  Developments in the electricity sector of neighboring Kazakhstan were substantially 
different from those in Tajikistan and the Kyrgyz Republic. After the independence in 1991, 
Kazakhstan’s power sector was at the forefront of introducing a liberalized multimarket model—
consisting of bilateral, spot, balancing, ancillary, and capacity submarkets. The sector was 
regarded as a market reform leader among countries of the former Soviet Union, having achieved 
much improved supply and demand balance and service quality compared to its peers.  
 
11.  However, despite the noteworthy headway, the sector reforms remain predominantly 
unfinished and in recent years, were rstateolled back in liberalizing the wholesale market. The 
halting of the country’s power generation privatization program has resulted in: (i) the decrease 
in strategic foreign investment; (ii) the reduction of liquidity of the earlier thriving spot market; and 
(iii) the re-emergence of excessive government control over the market. The government owns 
and controls the JSC Samruk-Energy, the largest electricity generator, and the Kazakhstan 
Electricity  Grid  Operating  Company  (KEGOC).  As  a  result,  the  sector  faces  the  following 
challenges: (i) high energy intensity; (ii) formidable investment requirements; and (iii) ineffective 
regulation and sector reform reversal. According to the World Bank, $42 billion in investments are 
required by 2030 only in generation to meet the targets set by the government.2 To achieve this, 
there is an urgent need for high-level screening and preliminary assessments of potential project 
opportunities  for  the  planned  Energy  Sector  Development  Program  or  a  new  project  and 
identification of financing structures.  
 
1 Most of the preparatory work for Sector Development Program was done under G0213-TAJ: Regional Power 
Transmission Project. However, complexity of reforms envisaged under the project requires additional financing. 
2 The World Bank. 2017.  Stuck in Transition: Reform Experiences and Challenges Ahead in The Kazakhstan Power 
Sector. Washington, D.C.

3 
 
12.  Overall, the energy sectors of the Central Asian countries are in a phase of dynamic 
transformations. These are catalyzed by a number of regional initiatives such as the Energy 
Sector Coordinating Committee under Central Asian Regional Cooperation (CAREC) and the 
Central Asian Regional Electricity Market initiative of the United States Agency for International 
Development. ADB is actively involved in a number of regional energy infrastructure projects, 
refurbishment of CAPS Coordinating Dispatch Center, and other initiatives supporting regional 
energy trade. Extensive technical expertise and in-depth knowledge of CAPS system is required 
in identification and design of electricity infrastructure projects of regional importance.

C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The TA facility is estimated to cost $1,775,000 of which (i) $175,000 will be financed on a 
grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-6), and (ii) $1,600,000 will be 
financed on a grant basis by the People’s Republic of China Poverty Reduction and Regional 
Cooperation Fund (PRC Fund),3 which will be  administered by ADB. The key expenditure items 
are listed in Appendix 1. 
 
15.  The governments were informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance 
any ensuing projects. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  ADB will administer the TA. CWEN will select, administer, and evaluate consultants. 
CWEN will supervise the consultants’ outputs to be delivered for the respective ensuing projects. 
The implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 2. 
 
Table 2: Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects  Arrangements 
Indicative implementation period  July 2019 – December 2020  
Executing agency  Asian Development Bank 
Consultants  To be selected and engaged by ADB 
  Firm: fixed budget  Project due diligence  $500,000 
selection  
  Individual: individual  International, 52  $1,100,000 
selection or as resource  person-months, and 
person  national 35 person-
months 
Advance contracting  To expedite the conduct of the TA, selection of consultants will commence 
through advance contracting following PAI 2.04. Negotiations and signing of 
the consulting contract will only occur after TA becomes effective.  
Disbursement  The TA resources will be disbursed following ADB's Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
ADB = Asian Development Bank, PAI = project administration instruction, TA = technical assistance.  
Source: Asian Development Bank staff estimates. 
 
17.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions.4 Any consulting position identified at a later stage will be recruited 
through individual consultant selection. 
 
18.  Cofinancier requirements. ADB will provide the PRC fund with annual progress reports 
and additional updates (as necessary) on project implementation. For major changes in scope, 
duration or funding arrangements, draft memos will be circulated to the PRC fund for review.  
 
3 The fund was originally named “People’s Republic of China Regional Cooperation and Poverty Reduction Fund” in 
the 2005 Board paper. 
4  Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

5 
 
II.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding 
the equivalent of $1,600,000 to be financed on a grant basis by People’s Republic of China 
Poverty Reduction and Regional Cooperation Fund, and (ii) ADB providing the balance not 
exceeding the equivalent of $175,000 on a grant basis to Kyrgyz Republic, Tajikistan, and 
Kazakhstan for Preparing Sustainable Energy Projects in Central Asia, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.
